Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dimensions US-Biota Sao Paulo: Chemically mediated multi-trophic interaction diversity across tropical gradients
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will examine the diversity and ecological complexity of plants and associated insects in forests across a variable landscape in Brazil. Plants, insects, and their predators make up over half of all known organisms, and their interactions are essential to ecosystem health. This is especially true for tropical forests, where ecologists are only beginning to understand the nature and complexity of these interactions. In particular, little is known about: 1) the diversity of plant chemicals that deter insect herbivory and affect other plants and animals, 2) how diversity of these plant chemicals varies within and between plant species, and 3) how plant chemistry can affect the diversity and productivity of entire forests. Recent advances in chemistry and molecular biology provide the opportunity to understand the diversity of plant-insect interactions at three different levels (chemical, genetic, and taxonomic) with unprecedented scope and depth. These new methods will be integrated and enhanced by a unique team of U.S. and Brazilian scientists to investigate the diversity of insect-plant food webs, how they are shaped by plant chemical defenses and environmental gradients, and how this diversity affects forest stability and productivity. The research will contribute to understanding how large global changes in biodiversity and climate will affect plant-insect-predator interactions, how plant genetic and chemical diversity influences plant-feeding, and how taxonomic and genetic diversity of insect predators can affect control of harmful insects. The comprehensive sampling and methods used in this project will result in the discovery of new species of plants and insects, new biologically active molecules, and are likely to deliver new tools and approaches that have powerful applications in agriculture and medicine. This international and multi-disciplinary research project will have broad impacts by involving K-12 students, science teachers, and citizen scientists. Discoveries will be widely communicated to the public via websites, and scientific and popular publications.

This project is focused on a highly diverse system involving plants in the genus Piper (Piperaceae), associated herbivores, and parasitic wasps and flies. The research will utilize cutting edge approaches to studying biodiversity that link measures of interaction diversity to genetic diversity, population genetic structure, and plant chemical diversity involving the following components: 1) Large scale sampling of herbivores and their parasitoids on diverse Piper species across an array of sites to assess effects of abiotic gradients on community structure and ecosystem processes, and to acquire specimens for taxonomic, genomic, and phytochemical analysis. 2) Field experiments where taxonomic, genetic, and functional diversity will be manipulated along with abiotic factors to strengthen inferences from statistical analysis of field surveys, community genetics, and measures of metabolite diversity. 3) Taxonomic and systematic analysis of plants, herbivores, and parasitoids using traditional and novel methods (genomics) to document and describe new taxa, understand their relationships, and reveal cryptic diversity. 4) Population genomic analyses of plants, herbivores, and parasitoids to understand how geography, plant phylogeny and chemistry influence population structure and genetic differentiation across trophic levels. 5) Characterization of metabolite diversity of Piper species; how metabolite diversity varies with phylogeny, ecology, and herbivore pressure; and the effect of phytochemical diversity on higher trophic levels. The combination of quantitative sampling along elevational gradients, newly developed metabolomics methods, population genomics, and a large scale experiment will make possible tests of emerging hypotheses about relationships between plant chemistry, and different dimensions of diversity, and will represent the first large scale, among-site plant-herbivore-parasitoid food-web comparison in the tropics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dimensions: Tritrophic Interaction Diversity as a Unified Axis for Studies of Metabolomic, Genomic, and Taxonomic Diversity across Broad Geographic Gradients

This collaborative research between ecologists and chemists in the USA and Brazil examined the diversity and ecological complexity of plants and associated insects in forests across the Americas. The diversity of interactions between plants, insects, and their predators makes up a significant proportion of overall biodiversity and is a key component of ecosystem health. This is especially true for tropical forests, where ecologists are only beginning to understand the nature and complexity of these interactions. The collaborative group focused on the diversity of plant chemicals that deter insect herbivory and affect other plants and animals, how diversity of these plant chemicals varies within and between plant species, and how plant chemistry can affect the diversity and stability of entire forests. In addition to discovering new chemical compounds found in tropical plants and describing new species of insects, we discovered novel interactions between plants and insects that are driven by plant chemistry. Figure 1 provides examples of the new species, chemicals, and interactions discovered in the course of this project. The focal plant species was the tropical shrub, Piper, and the drawing depicts a focal species, Piper sancti-felicis and a novel alkenyl-phenol (plant chemical) characterized from this plant by this project. We demonstrated that this and other novel compounds are important for mediating plant interactions with bats and insects. The new species and interactions associated with this plant and its unique chemistry included hundreds of species of caterpillars and associated wasp and fly parasites – Figure 1 depicts Eois caterpillars in the family Geometridae, all of which specialize on Piper plant species, and a wasp parasite of Eois, Glypantales bobkuli (Braconidae).

 Intellectual Merit: The proposal included a synthesis of molecular and ecological approaches to the study of species interactions and how they shape and are shaped by multiple dimensions of diversity. Among the approaches that this project brought together are unique methods for characterizing the diversity of plant chemistry, large-scale field experiments, new species descriptions, and the most recent advances in genetics. Understanding complex tropical food webs is important for biodiversity theory and conservation but poses challenges best addressed by large collaborative teams with a diverse suite of tools. We accomplished the following goals: (1) documented substantial changes in diversity of plant chemistry and plant-caterpillar-parasite food web structure across latitudinal, climatic, and elevational gradients, (2) found support for longstanding hypotheses about how genetics and environment affect plant chemical diversity, (3) demonstrated strong predictable patterns of ecological specialization along latitudinal and elevational gradients, (4) presented evidence supporting prominent evolutionary hypotheses about caterpillar specialization on plants, and (5) established efficient and rapid means of biodiversity discovery for new plant chemicals and complex webs of plants and insects.

 Broader Impacts: Broader impacts included participation of well over 100 Earthwatch volunteers, parataxonomists, senior scientists, research associates, graduate students, and undergraduates. The project also fostered new collaborations among chemists and ecologists in the USA, Brazil, Mexico, Costa Rica, Peru, and Argentina and linked the study of biodiversity across unique forests in the Americas. Activities in these different countries accomplished the following broader impacts: (1) built capacity in natural products chemistry, ecology, systematics, entomology, and botany through student training, (2) strengthened 5 prominent field research stations in South America, (3) expanded biological research collections in the USA and South America, and (4) disseminated data through searchable electronic databases. Field research had a direct impact on forest conservation through local outreach and education efforts. This collaboration brought together new collaborators, novel techniques, and new sites to combine cutting-edge research with training and outreach.

Integration: We used experimental and observational approaches to integrate different measures of biodiversity, combining methods from multiple disciplines, including chemistry, genetics, statistics, and ecology. Evolutionary history, soil resources, and water availability, for example, affect the distribution of genetic variation and genetic differentiation, which in turn contribute to species diversity and variation in plant chemistry (functional diversity). By quantifying these connections, we contributed to a better understanding of key ecosystem properties, including stability and productivity. Our team of researchers from across the Americas successfully integrated the different facets of biodiversity via an exciting mix of novel approaches to rapidly increase our understanding of biodiversity. Our publications on multi-trophic interaction diversity will continue to be extremely useful for understanding complex relationships between diversity and ecosystem services.
